brands.name: Nike
brands.hint: Founded by a track coach who poured rubber on a waffle iron to create the first sole. The name comes from the Greek goddess of victory.

brands.name: Adidas
brands.hint: The name comes from founder Adolf 'Adi' Dassler. His brother Rudolf started Puma after a family dispute during WWII.

brands.name: Puma
brands.hint: Founded by Rudolf Dassler after splitting from his brother Adi (who founded Adidas). The brothers' feud divided their entire hometown.

brands.name: Apple
brands.hint: The bite was added to ensure people wouldn't confuse it with a cherry. Steve Jobs worked at an apple farm before starting the company.

brands.name: Microsoft
brands.hint: The four colors represent different product lines: blue for Windows, green for Xbox, red for Office, and yellow for Bing.

brands.name: Google
brands.hint: Originally called 'BackRub', it was renamed after 'googol' (1 followed by 100 zeros), misspelled during domain registration.

brands.name: Amazon
brands.hint: The arrow represents that Amazon sells everything from A to Z, and also forms a smile. Originally sold only books.

brands.name: Twitter
brands.hint: The bird is named Larry after NBA legend Larry Bird. A tweet was limited to 140 characters to fit in a single SMS message.

brands.name: Instagram
brands.hint: The original logo was a Polaroid-style camera. The app was created in just 8 weeks and sold to Facebook for $1 billion.

brands.name: Spotify
brands.hint: The name is a combination of 'spot' and 'identify'. Founded in Sweden as a legal alternative to music piracy.

brands.name: Netflix
brands.hint: Started as a DVD-by-mail service. The famous 'ta-dum' sound was created to be recognizable in just 3 seconds.

brands.name: YouTube
brands.hint: The first video uploaded was 'Me at the zoo' by co-founder Jawed Karim, lasting just 18 seconds.

brands.name: PlayStation
brands.hint: Originally developed as a CD-ROM add-on for Nintendo. When Nintendo backed out, Sony created their own console.

brands.name: Xbox
brands.hint: The name comes from 'DirectX Box'. Microsoft lost money on every original Xbox sold, profiting only from game sales.

brands.name: Mercedes
brands.hint: The three points represent domination of land, sea, and air. Named after a car dealer's daughter, Mercedes.

brands.name: BMW
brands.hint: The logo represents a spinning aircraft propeller against a blue sky. BMW originally made airplane engines.

brands.name: Audi
brands.hint: Each ring represents one of four companies that merged in 1932: Audi, DKW, Horch, and Wanderer.

brands.name: Toyota
brands.hint: The overlapping ovals symbolize the heart of the customer, the product, and technological progress.

brands.name: Volkswagen
brands.description: V and W stacked in a circle
brands.hint: Means 'People's Car' in German. The Beetle was commissioned by Hitler but became a symbol of the 1960s counterculture.

brands.name: Ferrari
brands.hint: The horse was originally a WWI fighter pilot's lucky emblem. Enzo Ferrari was offered it by the pilot's mother.

brands.name: McDonald's
brands.hint: The arches were originally part of the restaurant architecture. A psychologist said they resembled 'mother's breasts' making them subconsciously appealing.

brands.name: Starbucks
brands.hint: Named after Starbuck, the first mate in Moby Dick. The siren was chosen because Seattle has a maritime history.

brands.name: Coca-Cola
brands.hint: Originally contained cocaine from coca leaves and caffeine from kola nuts. The red color helped identify it during Prohibition.

brands.name: Pepsi
brands.hint: Originally called 'Brad's Drink'. The current logo reportedly cost $1 million to redesign, inspired by the Mona Lisa and Earth's magnetic field.

brands.name: KFC
brands.hint: Colonel Sanders' secret recipe with 11 herbs and spices is kept in a vault. He was rejected by 1,009 restaurants before his first yes.

brands.name: Burger King
brands.hint: The logo is literally a burger in a bun. Burger King was originally called 'Insta-Burger King' before the name was shortened.

brands.name: Red Bull
brands.description: Two red bulls facing each other
brands.hint: Based on a Thai energy drink called Krating Daeng. Red Bull owns a Formula 1 team and a football club.

brands.name: Chanel
brands.hint: Coco Chanel never married. She popularized the 'little black dress' and Chanel No. 5 was the first perfume to bear a designer's name.

brands.name: Louis Vuitton
brands.hint: Louis Vuitton started as a trunk-maker for Napoleon III's wife. The monogram was created to prevent counterfeiting in 1896.

brands.name: Lacoste
brands.hint: Founded by tennis player René Lacoste, nicknamed 'the Crocodile' for his tenacity on court and a bet involving an alligator skin suitcase.

brands.name: WWF
brands.hint: The panda was chosen because it was black and white (cheap to print) and is a beloved endangered species. Chi-Chi the panda inspired it.

brands.name: Red Cross
brands.hint: The symbol is an inverted Swiss flag to honor Henry Dunant, the Swiss founder. In Muslim countries, a Red Crescent is used instead.

brands.name: Olympics
brands.hint: The five rings represent the five inhabited continents. At least one of the six colors (including white) appears in every national flag.

brands.name: NASA
brands.description: Blue circle with stars and orbit
brands.hint: The 'meatball' logo was retired in 1975 for the 'worm' logo but brought back in 1992. It features a red chevron for aeronautics.

brands.name: Airbnb
brands.hint: The founders initially sold cereal boxes called 'Obama O's' and 'Cap'n McCain's' to fund the startup during the 2008 election.

brands.name: Uber
brands.hint: Originally called UberCab, they dropped 'Cab' after legal pressure. The name means 'super' or 'topmost' in German.

brands.name: Tesla
brands.hint: The T represents a cross-section of an electric motor. Named after inventor Nikola Tesla who pioneered AC electricity.

brands.name: Porsche
brands.hint: The horse comes from Stuttgart's coat of arms, where Porsche is headquartered. Ferdinand Porsche also designed the VW Beetle.

brands.name: Shell
brands.hint: Started as a shop selling oriental seashells in London. The pecten (scallop) shell has been used since 1904.

brands.name: Mastercard
brands.hint: The overlapping circles were designed to represent the connection between consumers and merchants worldwide.

brands.name: Visa
brands.hint: Originally called BankAmericard. 'Visa' was chosen because it's easily pronounced in any language and evokes universal acceptance.

brands.name: FedEx
brands.description: Purple and orange text with hidden arrow
brands.hint: There's a hidden arrow between the E and x, representing speed and precision. The founder got a C on his Yale paper proposing the idea.

brands.name: Amazon Prime
brands.hint: Prime was launched in 2005 offering free 2-day shipping for $79/year. Employees thought it was too expensive—it now has 200+ million members.
